newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian employment falling - corrected trend.
newsitem.headline: Australian employment falling - corrected trend.

text.p: Trend estimates corrected for the distortions of telephone interviewing show Australian employment falling slightly, contrasting with the flat picture shown in published data.
The unemployment rate is rising slightly, but tending to flatten, according to a Reuters recalculation of the data prepared with the assistance of the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
(A full table of recalculated data since January 1996 is shown at the foot of this report.)
The corrected data shows that employment peaked in December at 8,424,400 and by April had fallen to 8,409,600 with the latest trend monthly fall of 5,600.
By contrast, the published data shows virtually zero trend change in employment.
Unemployment on the corrected trend series is 8.7 percent in both March and April, although rounding hides a continuing rise. The data shows stronger rises since a November trough.

The bureau says the phase-in of telephone interviewing last year initially understated employment levels for a few months, greatly distorting rates of change in jobs growth, unemployment and participation between August and February.

The bureau's April labour force data, published on Thursday, has not been corrected for this effect because the bureau cannot allocate the distortions among very small components of the data, such as part-time employment among young people in a particular state.
Instead, it encourages analysts to correct the major labour force figures themselves.
